document: Chapter 1: Understanding The Digital Forensics Profession and Investigations - Guide to Computer Forensics and Investigations, Fifth Edition

questions.question: Digital forensics is the application of computer science and investigative procedures for a legal purpose.
ISO 27037 is a standard for digital forensics that was ratified in 2010.
Data recovery and digital forensics are the same discipline.
The investigations triad includes vulnerability assessment, network intrusion detection, and digital investigations.
IACIS introduced training on digital forensics software in the early 2000s.
Case law is used when existing statutes don't keep up with technological change.
Public-sector investigations focus on policy violations, while private-sector investigations involve criminal prosecution.
The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act was passed in 1996.
A Digital Evidence First Responder (DEFR) has the skill to analyze data and determine when specialists should be called.
An affidavit is a sworn statement of support of facts about or evidence of a crime.
Private-sector investigations can involve email harassment and industrial espionage.
An acceptable use policy defines rules for using a company's computers and networks.
Warning banners on computer screens can help businesses avoid litigation.
In a BYOD environment, personal devices are never subject to company rules.
Professional conduct for investigators includes maintaining objectivity and confidentiality.
Chain of custody refers to the route evidence takes from discovery until case closure.
Computers cannot contain information that helps determine the chain of events leading to a crime.
Employee misuse of company resources can cost millions of dollars.
An evidence custody form is also called a chain-of-evidence form.
Evidence bags should be used to secure and catalog digital evidence.
When securing computer evidence, antistatic bags are not necessary.
Initials on evidence tape prove that evidence has not been tampered with.
The first step in problem solving for digital forensics is to analyze and recover digital evidence.
Employee termination cases rarely involve abuse of corporate assets.
For internet abuse investigations, you need the organization's proxy server logs.
Email abuse investigations require access to the suspect's computer for forensic analysis.
Attorney-client privilege rules require investigators to keep all findings public.
A computer forensics workstation is a specially configured PC loaded with additional bays and software.
Write-blockers are unnecessary for digital forensics workstations.
A basic digital forensics workstation requires a write-blocker device and acquisition tools.
When gathering evidence, you should meet the IT manager and have them sign the evidence form.
A bit-stream copy is the same as a simple backup copy.
Backup software can copy deleted files and email messages.
The first rule of computer forensics is to analyze the original evidence directly.
Deleted files remain on disk until new data overwrites the same physical location.
Public-sector investigations typically require search warrants before seizing digital evidence.
A systematic approach is unnecessary for digital forensics investigations.
Corporate-policy violations cannot go to court.
Internet abuse investigations do not require examining server log data.
You should always critique your own work in digital forensics.
